I am instincted to ask that the of the Independent State of the Congo will immediately take steps to cause the restoration of the steamer in question to her legitimate owners, the American Baptist Union at Stanley Port and that the Government will cause a searching investigation to be made of the arbitrary acts said to have been done in this regard, by the authorities of the State. Also that a prompt and effective reparation be made for any injury done to the owners by reason of the forcible seizure of the Steamers.
I avail myself og the opportunity to to you, Sir, the assurances of my most distinguished consideration.
Enclosure Copy of letter from A. Billington to the American Consul at St. Paul de Lounds dated August 3rd 1887.
American Baptist Missionary Union Stanley Port. Congo Free State August 3rd 1887
To the American Consul, St. Paul de Lounds

The above Society has a small Steamer on the waters of the Upper Congo for the purpose of conveying to us to be necessary to have "papers" on Steamer still a few weeks aho. It has recently become necessary. In the first place for the protection of the Mission property and in the Second place, because, that after the 1st Sept. 1887 we are compelled to fly the flag of the Congo Free State but we are not allowed to fly any other flag until we have the proper papers of our nationality on board

In when Mr. Stanley arrived here: he applied for the use of our steamer, but our circumstances that we could do as he wished he then attempted to take the steamer by force, by placing an armed band at the of our Mission Station, and another at the place where our steamer was at another and then sent in a letter demanding the instant surrender of the steamer; in the case of my not complying his officers had orders to enforce the demand at any risk either to myself or those concerened.

Before anything was done, the chief of the station of the "Congo Free State" at this place, protested against Mr. Stanley's action in the regime of the Staet, and the armed forces were withdrawn. The chief of the Station of the Free State then applied for the steamer, but our circumstances remaining unaltered qe were obliged to refuse.

It however, became very clear to us from conversation and correspondance that the steamer would be taken, so that we ultimately handed her over to the Free State under protest for Mr. Stanley's use for the space of 45 days. She
considerably beyond this zone by Mr. Stanley but after she had been sent away by him to be returned to us, before reaching here she seized by another officer of the Free State.

This seizure took place at the State Station by Lieut. Vangele . This officer first applied for the use of the steamer of the English Baptist Mission, she being there at the same time, but being refused at once armed soldiers on board the "Henry Reed". His action was protested against by some of in charge of the steamer but without effect the steamer has not yet been returned to us.

It was only yesterday that we received the decree of the King respecting flags, and now we write to ask if you wil kindly arrange for us get the "Papers" as early as possible that we may be able to use the American Flag.
I enclose particulars of the steamer and hope they will meet all requirememnts.
I have the honor, voc., A. Billington Member of the American Baptist Mission Union and in charge of the Fair Steamer
